concept.title: SQL Query for Incremental Mode
concept.shortdesc: When you define the SQL query for incremental mode, JDBC Query Consumer requires a WHERE and ORDER BY clause in the query.

conbody.p: Use the following guidelines when you define the WHERE and ORDER BY clauses in the query:

dlentry.dt: In the WHERE clause, include the offset column and the offset value
dlentry.dd: The origin uses an offset column and value to determine the data that is returned. Include both in the WHERE clause of the query.

dlentry.dt: Use the OFFSET constant to represent the offset value
dlentry.dd: In the WHERE clause, use ${OFFSET} to represent the offset value.

For example, when you start a pipeline, the following query returns all data from the table where the data in the offset column is greater than the initial offset value:SELECT * FROM <tablename> WHERE <offset column> > ${OFFSET}When the offset values are strings, enclose ${OFFSET} in single quotation marks.

dlentry.dt: In the ORDER BY clause, include the offset column as the first column
dlentry.dd: To avoid returning duplicate data, use the offset column as the first column in the ORDER BY clause.

dd.note: Using column that is not a primary key or indexed column in the ORDER BY clause can slow performance.

conbody.p: For example, the following query for incremental mode returns data from an Invoice table where the ID column is the offset column. The query returns all data where the ID is greater than the offset and orders the data by the ID: SELECT * FROM invoice WHERE id > ${OFFSET} ORDER BY id
